file_content.text: These Talz have no fear. Even when their army is at its last breath, they want to take us down with them.
If they kill the power station, we'll have no heat. We'll have to evacuate, or we won't last past nightfall.
Don't tell me you didn't think of this.
Now we find this out?
The station's guards won't be able to hold off the entire Talz force.
I'll stop them.
Every available gun needs to be saving that station.
Send in the troops!
We can't send everyone. What if they expect that and surprise us here?
I'll call for reinforcements from Adamas Orbital. They should be able to land within the hour.
Just get to that power station, and quickly!
Here. Let it not be said that carrying such a load through wampas is impossible.
Your cargo, Captain Yudrass. In one piece, as am I.
Yes, my lord. You will be pleased to know that we have kept up our end of the plan.
The base is prepared for war. We have security fields, sensors, anti-personnel guns... we'll obliterate any Talz that dares approach.
Here you are. Watch out, the Talz will want this back.
I believe you requested Talz supplies, Captain Yudrass.
Excellent. I will search through this once the coming battle is over.
Which won't be long. Our sensors will catch the Talz, and our anti-personnel guns will obliterate them.
It is done. Everything the Talz owns is burnt or broken.
It is done. Nothing remains in the Talz cave but ice and debris.
The Talz will come home to find nothing but ashes.
Good. They will have no choice but to strike, and we are ready for them.
The Talz supplies are destroyed. Get ready for some angry payback.
We are more than ready. They will find us armed and deadly.
Commander! Commander! There's reports of a Talz attack.
Excellent! What wing are they headed for?
No wing, sir. They're at the power station. They're overrunning the guards. They brought bombs!
We have devised a plan to put the Talz in position for a killing blow.
Their supplies--weapons, medical equipment and the high-calorie food they require--all of it is stored in one central location.
They may be adapted to the cold, but without their supplies, they wouldn't last a week. So we will destroy their cache.
I crush foes and souls, not crates and barrels.
This is beneath me.
Hear me out, my lord. With supplies cut off, all the Talz will be forced to gather and unite on a course of action.
They will choose between retreating home or starvation.
Forcing a miserable choice.
That, or one other option that we think the more likely.
Blaster fire works faster than starvation.
Why not kill them directly?
We'd have to stalk them through the snow. But without supplies, all the Talz will come together to plan retribution.
What about their inevitable retaliation?
The Talz would hit back.
We expect it. No Talz commando will give up easily.
And then what?
We want them to panic and launch an all-out, last-ditch attack on us. And we'll be waiting.
So instead of fighting Talz, you want us to fight hungry, angry Talz.
That won't stop them long.
They should be able to mount one counterattack before hunger weakens them.
If I were them, and suddenly without food, I would raid this base. So we will amplify our defenses here and spring the trap shut.
Unfortunately, getting at their supplies may be difficult--they are in a series of ice caves overrun by wampas.
That sounds like a pretty unforgiving security system.
How do the Talz survive?
Wampas can be fooled. A combination of synthetic pheromones and body language could make them think a Talz is part of their pack.
Good. A proper fight.
If that is the case, I suggest an alternative.
We are desperately short on supplies here.
If you could bring back all you find, it could make a valuable difference.
But we'd need over a hundred kilos of food alone. How would anyone carry that and still fight?
Is there anything important on this planet that isn't in some snow creature's freezer?
More ice and more caves?
I suspect taking over a cave was faster than digging their own shelter. Though I'm not sure how they dominate the wampas.
All the more reason to bring back their equipment. We could learn much from the Talz.
The last thing you'd want to do in a wampa cave is weigh yourself down.
You'd be surprised how much I can carry.
I'll bring the supplies back.
I suspect, even with your associates here, it will be difficult. But it's your decision.
Daring, my lord. I hope you're making the right call.
Very well, then. Who am I to say if you've gone mad?
Take anything of theirs that gives them aid or comfort. Make them come crawling.
Between Talz and wampas, I'll need both hands free.
I'll destroy the cache.
Then it's settled. Destroy anything of use to them.
Let them know who the masters of this miserable world are.
Yudrass is here... ah, sir! The reprisal was successful. Look to the holocom.
Good work. Has the base been informed? How is morale there?
Gentlemen, the commander wants to know how we feel about the Talz being struck down.
Excellent. That's a sound I have not heard in some time.
And I understand one of our patrols spotted Talz that fled rather than fight. The tides of war are with us.
Without the advantage of surprise, the Talz are showing their true colors.
They are frightened.
Yes, we'll let them panic for a while as they try to figure out which body is which.
Next moves?
Your men smell blood. Time to deliver it to them.
We will bury the Republic.
I couldn't agree more.
Good to hear from you. We've been receiving the feed from the data arrays, and what we learned is quite interesting.
We had assumed there were one, perhaps two groups of Talz out there. We found six.
Had we attacked earlier, we would have gotten one group and the other five would have gone to ground.
Now that we've tracked them, it is time to exterminate them.
They cannot run now.
Commander Tritan and I believe we have the answer.
I did well... again.
Hmm. I will not underestimate the Talz. Complacency is what got the colonel killed.
Planning makes the victory greater.
Let this be a lesson, Tritan.
It certainly paid off in this case. Unfortunately, we have one more step to take.
The good part is, we know how many Talz there are. The bad part is, we don't have enough forces to hit all six groups at once.
Yes? Yes, you're coming in loud and clear. Good to see you're all accounted for.
Hello? Good to see you, my lord, we feared the worst.
[This holocommunicator is currently switched off.]
